thread.title: What's on: Your guide to the best Sydney attractions from October 25
thread.title_full: What's on: Your guide to the best Sydney attractions from October 25

author: Nicole Elphick
title: What's on: Your guide to the best Sydney attractions from October 25
text:
See a rooftop screening of Ridley Scott's Blade Runner. Photo: Supplied 
Sunday October 25 ART Sydney favourite Sculpture by the Sea (until November 8) is on now, overlooking Bondi waters. More than 100 works from international and local artists are strung along the coastline, making the view even more photogenic.  Dawn to dusk, Bondi to Tamarama coastal walk, free, sculpturebythesea.com. 
TALK Expect to hear tummies rumbling at How I Eat , a Good Food Month discussion on dining and deliciousness held between Lucky Peach editor Chris Ying, Pulitzer Prize-winning critic Jonathan Gold and the Herald 's Terry Durack. Afterwards, audiences member can catch the Sydney premiere screening of Gold's documentary City of Gold . 10am, Art Gallery NSW, Art Gallery Road, The Domain, city, $35, sydney. goodfoodmonth.com. 
Artist Jeremy Sheehan installing the Trans Migration mutton birds for Sculpture by the Sea. Photo: James Brickwood 
COMMUNITY Hit up Leichhardt for the giant festival, Norton Street Festa. The very Italian bash has a bustling marketplace, cooking demonstrations on regional cuisine and a display of cars, motorbikes and scooters. 10am-5pm, Norton Street, Leichhardt, free, nortonstreetfesta.com.au. 
Advertisement Monday October 26  STAGE Neglected Musicals specialise in works rarely seen in Australia and for their new production they've chosen the 1993 Broadway romantic comedy The Goodbye Girl , based on Neil Simon's 1977 film of the same name. 2pm and 8pm, Hayes Theatre Co, 19 Greenknowe Avenue, Potts Point, $40, 8065 7337, hayestheatre.com.au. 
Robbie Williams will perform at the Allphones Arena, Sydney Olympic Park. Photo: Supplied 
MUSIC Sydney Harmony Men's Chorus hold an open rehearsal so any prospective new singers can get a glimpse of the all-male a cappella choir performing their barbershop four-part harmonies. 7.30pm, Ron Dyer Centre, corner Miller and Ridge streets, North Sydney, free, sydneyharmony.com.au.
Tuesday October 27 FILM  More than 30 flicks are on the schedule at the BBC First British Film Festival (until November 18). The opening event movie is Paolo Sorrentino's​ Palme d'Or-nominated Youth , starring Michael Caine and Harvey Keitel as two old friends holidaying in the Swiss Alps.  7pm, Palace Norton Street, 99 Norton Street, Leichhardt, $50, 9564 5620, britishfilmfestival.com.au. 
On Sunday, November 1, Sydney Open throws open the doors to city treasures such as the St James Station tunnels. Photo: Anthony Browell 
MUSIC  That great showman of modern pop Robbie Williams (until October 28) is out to play his biggest hits and a few covers at an arena spectacle. Sway along to global hits like Angels , Rock DJ and Better Man .  7.30pm, Allphones Arena, Sydney Olympic Park, $109-$199, 132 849, ticketek.com.au. 
Wednesday October 28 BOOKS  Author and social commentator Jane Caro chats about her recently released memoir Plain-Speaking Jane . In the book, she discusses her battle with an anxiety disorder and experiences of sexism in the advertising industry.  12.30pm, State Library, Macquarie Street, city, free (bookings essential), 9273 1414, sl.nsw.gov.au. 
COMEDY  Have some laughs for a good cause at The Wilderness Society's funny fundraiser, Green Comedy Roast. Catch quips from American stand-up Paul Ogata and a guest appearance from Wendy Harmer.  8pm, Comedy Store, The Entertainment Quarter, 207/122 Lang Road, Moore Park, $40, 9357 1419, wilderness.org.au. 
Thursday October 29 FAMILY  The popular children's character returns to the stage with Peppa Pig Live! Big Splash (until November 1). Little ones can sing along to the tunes and follow the puppet action as Peppa and her friends work to fix a leaking nursery roof.  12.30pm and 4pm, Roslyn Packer Theatre, 22 Hickson Road, Walsh Bay, $29.90-$44.90, 9250 1999, roslynpackertheatre.com.au. 
BOOKS  Author and radio personality John Safran presents a return season of the show he created based on his best-selling true-crime title Murder in Mississippi (until November 1). Safran uses film and photography from his stint in America's deep south to bring the tale to life.  8pm, Giant Dwarf, 199 Cleveland Street, Redfern, $35, giantdwarf.com.au. 
Friday October 30 STAGE  Josh McConville​ and Matilda Ridgway delve into the violence and madness of Hamlet (until December 6) for Bell Shakespeare's production, directed by Damien Ryan.  7.30pm, Sydney Opera House, $79, 9250 7777, bellshakespeare.com.au. 
STAGE  After a revival on the West End, Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical Cats (until November 29) returns to Sydney. Pop star Delta Goodrem​ takes on the role of Grizabella​, putting her spin on the popular show tune Memory.  8pm, Capitol Theatre, 13 Campbell Street, Haymarket, $119.90-$139.90, 136 100, ticketmaster.com.au. 
Saturday October 31 FAMILY  Children aged five to 12 can have a little Halloween fun at Swamp Monsters. Youngsters will follow a map and complete challenges to collect candy while possibly spotting spooky creatures along the way. Afterwards, attendees can decorate a scarecrow.  10am-6pm, Learning Centre, Education Precinct, Dickens Drive, Centennial Park, $15, centennialparklands.com.au. 
PARTY  Get up for Bavarian shenanigans at Oktoberfest in the Gardens. Visitors can sip on a stein at the big-top beer hall, snack on treats at the authentic German food stalls or have a boogie at the silent disco.  2pm-10pm, Phillip Precinct, The Domain, city, $64.90, sydney.oktoberfestinthegardens.com.au. 
Sunday Nov 1 DESIGN  Peek inside more than 50 of the city's most architecturally important buildings at Sydney Open. Visitors can wander through and learn about structures including the State Library, the University of Technology Sydney building and the tunnels of St James station.  10am-4pm, throughout the city, $49, slm.is/open. 
MUSIC  Composer extraordinaire Burt Bacharach​ opens up his songbook for a concert alongside his band and vocalists. It must be a difficult set list to whittle down, given that Bacharach has written more than 70 top-40 US hits in his long-running career.  8pm, State Theatre, 49 Market Street, city, $89-$189, 136 100, ticketmaster.com.au. 
LOOKING AHEAD NEXT WEEK Michael Chabon, author of The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay , appears with his wife and fellow author Ayelet Waldman to discuss literature, creativity and how they find a balance between work and family.  November 3, Seymour Centre, corner City Road and Cleveland Street, Chippendale, $35, 9351 7940, swf.org.au. 
NEXT MONTH Watch the dystopian neo-noir of Ridley Scott's Blade Runner at a special More Human Than Human screening hosted by Golden Age Cinema in an inner-city car park. The event features a futuristic night market and a rooftop showing of the recently remastered flick.  November 21, 101 Goulburn Street, Haymarket, $20, artandabout.com.au. 
STAYING IN Mindy Kaling, the creator and star of sitcom The Mindy Project , this month released her new essay collection, Why Not Me?  In her usually witty style she gives a glimpse into her life in Hollywood and her thoughts on the fast-paced Los Angeles scene. $32.99 (Ebury)
